1 \defgroup session-storage Session Storage
2 
3 \details
4 
5 By default, the Handler uses \ref file-based-session-storage, so it stores incoming and
6 outgoing messages and session's state data in files in the OnixS::B3::BOE::SessionSettings::storageDirectory folder.
7 
8 However, it is possible to keep all session-related data in memory using the \ref memory-based-session-storage.
9 
10 Also, one can use asynchronous-file-based-session-storage, which combines excellent performance with
11 the \ref file-based-session-storage functionality.
12 
13 Yet another option is to use the \ref pluggable-session-storage.
14 
15 \section restoring-session-state Restoring Session State
16 
17 \details
18 
19 When the OnixS::B3::BOE::Session object is created, the session state (OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::sessionVerId,
20 OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::negotiated, OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::inSeqNum, OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::outSeqNum, etc.)
21 is restored from the session storage.
22 
23 To start a session as a new one (so-called "clean start"), either remove the session storage files from the previous runs
24 or call the OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::reset() method.
25 
26 When the session is finished, the session storage files are not needed anymore. They can be backed up,
27 and later a new FIXP session with a new \ref session-version-identification "SessionVerID"
28 will start \ref message-sequence-numbers "message sequence numbers" from `1`.
29 
30 The usual practice is to back up log files at the end of the business day (so-called "End Of Day procedure")
31 to generate a new \ref session-version-identification and start the sequence numbers from `1`
32 at the beginning of the next trading day.
33 
34 \see \ref message-sequence-numbers
35 \see \ref session-initialization-and-binding
36 \see \ref session-version-identification
